item.title: The Lede: Video of Police Brutality in Kiev Fuels Rage
item.description: Protesters and local journalists in Kiev documented a tumultuous weekend in the Ukrainian capital in online video.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Gunmen Attack Offices of Pakistani Media Group in Karachi
item.description: Nobody has claimed responsibility for the attack, the second in recent months, on the Express Media Group, but suspicion fell on the Pakistani Taliban.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Top U.N. Rights Official Links Assad to Crimes in Syria
item.description: The assertion by Navi Pillay, the high commissioner for human rights, about the Syrian leader was based on what she called information amassed by her panel of investigators.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Chinese Leader’s Rise Came With New Attention to Dispute With Japan
item.description: President Xi Jinping of China appears to have approved the new air defense zone devised to weaken Japan’s grip on disputed islands in the East China Sea.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping has amassed power in the past year.

item.title: Arts, Briefly: A First for Sotheby’s: An Auction in Beijing
item.description: Sotheby’s held its first commercial auction in mainland China on Sunday, according to Bloomberg News.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by ADAM W. KEPLER
item.media:credit: Zao Wou-Ki/2013 Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York / ADAGP, Paris

item.title: Somali Parliament Votes to Remove Prime Minister
item.description: A “constitutional dispute” between President Hassan Sheik Mohamud and Prime Minister Abdi Farah Shirdon resulted in a no-confidence vote.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: Biden Faces Delicate Two-Step in Asia Over East China Sea Dispute
item.description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. must reassure Japan of American support while confronting China on its imposition of an air defense zone over disputed islands.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrived in Tokyo on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Director Offers to Pay Fine for One-Child Policy Violation
item.description: Zhang Yimou, the prominent Chinese film director, acknowledged that he had two sons and a daughter with his current wife but denied rumors that he had seven children with four different women.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN

item.title: Thai Police Step Up Defense in Bangkok as Protests Continue
item.description: After a week of using soft-gloved tactics, the police on Monday stepped up their defense of government buildings in Bangkok, firing rubber bullets and tear gas at protesters.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: December 2
item.description: Japan’s Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko are on a state visit to India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Japan's Empress Michiko, left, being welcomed by Manmohan Singh, prime minister of India, in New Delhi. Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko are in India on a state visit to commemorate the 60th anniversary of bilateral diplomatic ties.

item.title: Letter From Europe: 'Anti-Racism' of the Left Reaps Scorn in France
item.description: The question of racism, and anti-racism, lingers in France, casting a shadow on the debate about immigration, about which resentment is growing daily.
item.dc:creator: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: News Analysis: In the East China Sea, a Far Bigger Test of Power Looms
item.description: In an era when the United States has been focused on new forms of conflict, the dangerous contest suddenly erupting in the East China Sea seems almost like a throwback to the Cold War.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: A group of islands in the East China Sea that both Japan and China claim to control. American officials are worried that a collision or other event in the area could rapidly escalate tensions.

item.title: Attacks Rise on Aid Workers in Afghanistan
item.description: Fatalities have more than tripled this year, making the country by far the most dangerous place in the world for relief work, according to United Nations officials.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Insurgents Strike in Major Nigerian City
item.description: The attack in Maiduguri raised doubts about official claims that the insurgents, known as Boko Haram, had been pushed into remote areas.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: The Lede: For Egypt’s New Rulers, Familiar Scapegoats
item.description: The arrest of an Egyptian activist whose blogging has made him the target of four successive governments seemed to signal that the security forces are intent on quashing dissent.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: India Ink: A Dalit Village Waits Uneasily for Justice
item.description: The recent acquittals of the men accused of killing 58 Dalits in Bihar are just the latest obstacle in the low-caste villagers’ struggle for equal rights.
item.dc:creator: By NEYAZ FAROOQUEE

item.title: Ukrainian Protesters Control Landmark Plaza
item.description: While Ukrainian leaders grappled over a growing protest movement, the government effectively ceded control of Independence Square to protesters demanding the president’s ouster.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Protesters seeking more integration with Europe and the West clashed with the police outside the office of President Viktor F. Yanukovich in Kiev on Sunday.

item.title: Lens Blog: In Olympic Sochi, a Photographic Pregame
item.description: Two months before the Winter Olympics begin in Sochi, Russia, a local photographer looks to cut through the noise and hype and reveal the Black Sea resort town he knows and loves.
item.dc:creator: By MATT MCCANN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Record Prices Set for 6 Artists at Sotheby’s Beijing Auction
item.description: A Chinese collector paid more than 89 million renminbi, or $14.7 million, for “Abstraction” by Zao Wou-ki, the Chinese-French painter who died in April.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A painting by Zao Wou-ki (below), “Abstraction,” sold for more than 89 million renminbi, or $14.7 million.

item.title: Death Toll at 9 in Scottish Copter Crash
item.description: The dead included all three people aboard the helicopter and six inside the pub that was hit on Friday night.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: India Ink: India’s One-Woman Tea Party
item.description: Like the upstart political movement in the United States, Ahalya Kandapan rails against wasted government funds and wants to shake up the status quo of the political establishment.
item.dc:creator: By ZACH MARKS
item.media:description: Residents of Kelar, Odisha, gathered around Ahalya Kandapan for a meeting on Nov. 20.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: CCTV Producer Says He Was Dismissed for Questioning Coverage
item.description: Wang Qinglei, who worked on prominent news programs including “24 Hours” and “Face to Face,” has written an open letter criticizing the state-run network for its role in China’s campaign to curb Internet gossip.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A image of Wang Qinglei's Sina Weibo account, which he used to post a letter criticizing coverage by his former employer, the state-run broadcaster China Central Television.

item.title: Merchandise Uses Olympics Principles Against Russian Anti-Gay Laws
item.description: In time for the Winter Games in Sochi, a prominent campaign is highlighting the anti-discrimination language of the Olympic charter.
item.dc:creator: By STUART ELLIOTT
item.media:description: Belle Brockhoff, an Australian snowboarder who came out as a lesbian and plans to compete in the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, will appear in Principle 6 merchandise on the American Apparel website as well as on a webiste, .

item.title: Natalya Gorbanevskaya, Soviet Dissident and Poet, Dies at 77
item.description: Ms. Gorbanevskaya was arrested after protesting the Soviet Union’s 1968 invasion of Czechoslovakia, and later confined to a psychiatric hospital for her writings.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: Thousands Demand Resignation of Ukraine Leader
item.description: The largest showing of fury in 11 days over President Viktor F. Yanukovich’s refusal to sign political and trade accords with the European Union came as signs of fissure emerged within the government.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Protesters seeking more integration with Europe and the West clashed with the police outside the office of President Viktor F. Yanukovich in Kiev on Sunday.
